title: 111_hr1645
content: The Act titled "Financial and Economic Literacy Improvement Act of 2009" introduces grants for financial and economic literacy education under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities to provide financial and economic literacy education and promote related activities. Eligible entities include State educational agencies or State partnerships with nonprofit organizations experienced in financial education. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities for professional development in financial and economic literacy education. Eligible entities must submit an application to receive the grant, and funds will be allotted to each State based on a formula. The funds must be used for activities related to financial education. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities for professional development in financial and economic literacy education, with funds to be used for activities related to financial education. Eligible local entities include local educational agencies or local partnerships with nonprofit organizations experienced in financial literacy. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities for professional development in financial and economic literacy education, including nonprofit organizations with experience in quality professional development for teachers leading to higher student achievement in skills integral to financial literacy. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities for professional development in financial and economic literacy education, including nonprofit organizations, institutions of higher education, community organizations, and local business representatives. Eligible entities receiving grants must use 75 percent of funds to award subgrants to local entities. Applications for subgrants will be accepted from eligible local entities. An eligible local entity seeking a subgrant must submit an application to the eligible entity with required information. The eligible entity will review applications similar to section 5534(b). Subgrant funds must be used for teacher training implementation. Implement teacher training programs to embed financial and economic literacy and personal finance education into core academic subjects or coordinate teaching effectively. Administer financial and economic literacy assessments annually in selected grade levels. Implement financial and economic literacy activities within core academic subjects, including after-school activities to enhance student understanding of consumer, economic, and personal finance concepts. Eligible local entities receiving subgrants must report student achievement information in annual report cards. The eligible entity receiving a grant must use 25% of funds for developing financial and economic literacy standards in 3 grade levels. The eligible entity receiving a grant must provide 25% matching funds for activities such as developing financial literacy assessments, teacher professional development programs, and evaluating the impact of financial education on students' understanding. Authorization of Appropriations: $125,000,000 authorized for fiscal years 2010 through 2015 to carry out activities under this section. SEC. 5539 establishes a Financial and Economic Literacy and Economic Education Clearinghouse. The Financial and Economic Literacy and Economic Education Clearinghouse, established by SEC. 5539, will maintain best practices, tools, and instructional materials for financial literacy aligned with curriculum standards for students of all ages. It will collect and distribute high-quality materials on financial literacy and provide accessibility to this information. The Literacy and Economic Education Clearinghouse, established by SEC. 5539, will be easily accessible online and funded through appropriations for fiscal years 2010 through 2015. "Sec. 318 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 amends Part A of title III to provide grants for promoting postsecondary financial and economic literacy." The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities, including institutions of higher education and partnerships with nonprofit organizations, to provide financial and economic literacy courses to students. Eligible entities must have experience in financial education programs and professional development for teachers. An eligible entity seeking a grant under this section must apply to the Secretary with necessary information. Grants will be awarded in amounts of at least $500,000 to support financial and economic literacy education initiatives that enhance student understanding of financial concepts. $125,000,000 is authorized for appropriations to implement this program. $125,000,000 is appropriated for fiscal years 2010 through 2015 to support financial and economic literacy education initiatives.
